userGuide.title: User Guide for Excel Power Tools
userGuide.description: Welcome to the User Guide! This section provides a detailed overview of each tool available in the application.

splitter.title: Sheet Splitter
splitter.description: The Sheet Splitter takes a master sheet and divides it into multiple new sheets within the same workbook. Each new sheet is named after a unique value found in a column you specify, and contains only the rows corresponding to that unique value.
splitter.whenToUse: Use this when you have a large dataset with a categorical column (like 'Region', 'Department', or 'Salesperson') and you need to create separate, organized reports for each category.
howToUse: Upload your Excel file.
Select the source sheet containing the master data.
Specify the row number where your headers are located.
Choose the column that will be used to split the data (the 'Identifier Column').
Optionally, reorder the columns for the output sheets.
Click 'Analyze & Preview' to see how many sheets will be created.
Click 'Download Split Workbook' to get your new file.
splitter.proTip: Use the 'Column Order' feature to create cleaner, more focused reports. You can exclude unnecessary columns from the final output sheets.

updater.title: Sheet Updater & Formatter
updater.description: The Sheet Updater is a powerful tool for applying consistent formatting and making structural changes across multiple sheets at once. It generates a VBScript macro to perform complex operations inside the workbook itself.
updater.whenToUse: Use this to standardize the appearance of reports, insert boilerplate headers, or add calculated columns to many sheets without manual effort.
howToUse: Upload your source Excel file.
Select all the sheets you wish to update.
Configure your desired formatting options (e.g., bold headers, custom text headers, new columns).
Review the generated VBScript preview to understand the actions that will be performed.
Click 'Update & Download File' to receive an .xlsm (macro-enabled) file with the changes.
updater.proTip: The Custom Column feature is great for creating unique IDs by splitting data from another column. For example, you can extract a project code from a string like 'ProjectX-Task1' by using '-' as the delimiter.

aggregator.title: Data Aggregator
aggregator.description: Analyze text across multiple sheets to count occurrences of specific keywords or phrases, based on your custom mapping rules.
aggregator.whenToUse: Use this when you need to categorize and summarize text-based data, such as survey responses, support tickets, or product descriptions.
howToUse: Upload your Excel file.
Select the sheets containing the text you want to analyze.
Specify the header row.
Enter the columns to search within.
Provide your list of keywords and their corresponding reporting keys in the 'Mappings' text area.
Choose a 'Match Mode' to control how keywords are found.
Click 'Analyze & Aggregate Data' to see the results.
Optionally, edit the final keys before downloading your report or modified workbook.
aggregator.proTip: Use the 'Key Match' mode with 'Discover New Keys' enabled to quickly get a count of every unique value in a category column without having to pre-define them.

merger.title: Sheet Merger & Combiner
merger.description: This tool has two modes: 'Merge' copies sheets from one workbook to another, while 'Combine' takes multiple sheets from a single workbook and stacks their data into one new sheet.
merger.whenToUse: Use 'Merge' to consolidate updated report tabs from a colleague into your master file. Use 'Combine' to create a master dataset from separate monthly or regional data sheets.
howToUse: Select 'Merge' or 'Combine' mode.
For 'Merge': Upload a source and a destination file, select sheets to copy over, and choose whether to replace existing sheets.
For 'Combine': Upload a single file, select all sheets you want to stack, and configure options like adding a 'Source Sheet' column.
Click the process button to generate and download your new file.
merger.proTip: When combining sheets, the tool automatically creates a superset of all headers. This means you don't have to worry if your sheets don't have the exact same column layout.

comparator.title: Excel Comparator
comparator.description: Compares two Excel files sheet by sheet based on a primary key, generating a detailed report of new, deleted, and modified rows.
comparator.whenToUse: Use this when you have two versions of a file (e.g., this month's data vs. last month's) and need to see exactly what has changed.
howToUse: Upload the 'File A' (original) and 'File B' (new) workbooks.
Specify the primary key column(s) that uniquely identify a row.
Select the common sheets you want to compare.
Click 'Compare Files' to see a summary of differences.
Optionally, use the 'Reconcile Workbook' feature to create a new file with the changes merged.
comparator.proTip: You can use multiple columns as a composite key by separating them with a comma (e.g., 'OrderID,ProductID'). This is useful when no single column can uniquely identify a row.

breaker.title: Workbook Breaker
breaker.description: The Workbook Breaker splits a large workbook with many sheets into multiple, smaller Excel files based on user-defined groups.
breaker.whenToUse: Use this when a workbook becomes too large and unwieldy, or when you need to distribute different sets of sheets to different teams or individuals.
howToUse: Upload your large workbook.
In the 'Sheet Grouping' table, assign a 'New Workbook Name' to each sheet.
Sheets with the same group name will be saved together in a new file with that name.
Use the 'Smart Breakup' tools to quickly assign groups.
Click 'Break Workbook' to process.
Download each of the newly created files from the results area.
breaker.proTip: Use the filter and bulk assign features to quickly group related sheets. For example, filter for all sheets containing 'Q1' and assign them to the 'Q1_Report' group.

finder.title: Empty Cell Finder
finder.description: Scan your workbook for empty or blank cells. You can choose to highlight them, generate a report, or both.
finder.whenToUse: Use this for data validation and cleaning to ensure your datasets are complete before analysis or reporting.
howToUse: Upload your Excel file.
Select the sheets you want to scan.
Specify which columns to check (or all columns).
Choose your options: highlight cells, generate a report, or both.
Click 'Find Empty Cells'.
Download the updated file with highlights and/or the report.
finder.proTip: The 'Summary' report format is powerful. It can create a pivot-table-style summary of empty cells, grouped by the values in other columns (e.g., show me empty 'Completion Date' cells, grouped by 'Project Manager').

duplicates.title: Duplicate Finder
duplicates.description: Find and optionally mark or highlight duplicate rows based on a composite key you define. This tool can write a status to a column, highlight the entire duplicate row, and generate a detailed report.
duplicates.whenToUse: Essential for data cleaning and ensuring data integrity. Use it to identify duplicate customer records, order entries, or any other redundant data before analysis.
howToUse: Upload your file and select sheets to check.
Define the 'Key Columns' that together make a row unique (e.g., 'Email', or 'FirstName,LastName').
Specify the 'Update Column' where a value like 'DUPLICATE' should be written.
Configure optional settings like row highlighting or conditional marking.
Click 'Find Duplicates & Mark'.
Download the marked file and/or the separate duplicate report.
duplicates.proTip: Use the 'Context' update mode to pull a value from the *first* instance of a record and write it to the duplicate rows. This is great for back-filling data, like populating an empty 'CustomerID' on duplicate entries.

columnPurger.title: Column Purger
columnPurger.description: Quickly remove one or more columns from multiple sheets at once, preserving all other data and formatting.
columnPurger.whenToUse: Use this to clean up files for distribution or to remove sensitive or unnecessary data from multiple report sheets simultaneously.
howToUse: Upload your Excel file.
Select all the sheets you want to modify.
Enter a comma-separated list of the columns you want to remove (e.g., 'A,C,Notes').
Click 'Purge Columns & Download'.
columnPurger.proTip: You can purge columns using either their letter (A, B) or their header name from the specified header row. Combining them works too (e.g., A,Status,C).

formatter.title: Text Formatter
formatter.description: Apply formatting (font style, color, fill, alignment) to cells that contain specific text or match a regular expression. This is a powerful way to visually highlight data across many sheets.
formatter.whenToUse: Use this to highlight all cells containing 'Error', format all negative numbers in red, or apply a specific style to cells matching a certain pattern (like a project code).
howToUse: Upload your workbook and select sheets.
Enter the text or regular expression to search for.
Choose your search options (e.g., match case, entire cell).
Select one or more formatting options to apply (font, fill, or alignment).
Configure the styles you want.
Click 'Find & Format Text' and download the updated file.
formatter.proTip: Use the Regex mode for powerful pattern matching. For example, to format all email addresses, you could use a regex pattern. Check the 'Regex Tips' for examples!

imputer.title: AI Smart Fill
imputer.description: Intelligently fills blank cells using either Generative AI to analyze context or rule-based logic to populate data based on duplicate key values.
imputer.whenToUse: Use AI mode when you have missing data that follows a logical pattern (e.g., filling in a 'Category' based on a 'Product Description'). Use Manual mode for rule-based filling, like populating a 'Department' based on an 'Employee ID' prefix.
howToUse: Upload your file and select the sheets and column to fill.
Choose your mode: 'AI' or 'Manual'.
For AI mode, specify context columns that help the AI understand the row's data.
For Manual mode, define the key and source columns for rule-based filling.
Click 'Get Suggestions' to see a preview of the proposed changes.
Approve the suggestions and download the imputed file.
imputer.proTip: For best results, use the AI mode on data with clear, logical patterns. For rule-based filling (like using a part number to fill in a product name), the Manual mode is faster and more reliable.

uniqueFinder.title: Unique Value Finder
uniqueFinder.description: Find all unique values from specified columns or substrings in text files (.txt, .csv) and get a count of each. It can also perform the reverse operation: removing lines from files that match a list of values.
uniqueFinder.whenToUse: Use 'Find' mode to quickly generate a list of all unique categories, tags, or IDs from raw data logs. Use 'Remove' mode to clean a master list by removing items found in another list.
howToUse: Select 'Find' or 'Remove' mode.
Upload one or more .txt or .csv files.
For 'Find' mode, configure how to extract values (from a specific column or using start/end delimiters).
For 'Remove' mode, paste the list of values (one per line) to be removed.
Click the process button.
Download the results report (for 'Find') or the cleaned file(s) (for 'Remove').
uniqueFinder.proTip: This tool works on multiple files at once! You can upload several .txt files to find unique values across all of them.

extractor.title: Data Extractor
extractor.description: Find all rows that match a specific value in a lookup column and extract data from specified return columns into a new report.
extractor.whenToUse: Use this when you need to pull all transactions for a specific customer, all logs for a certain event ID, or any scenario where you need to create a subset of your data based on a single criterion.
howToUse: Upload your workbook and select the sheet(s) to search in.
Specify the 'Lookup Column' and the 'Lookup Value' you want to find.
Enter the 'Return Columns' you want to include in the report. Use '*' to get all columns.
Click 'Extract Data'.
Download the generated Excel or PDF report from the results area.
extractor.proTip: The 'Scan for Values' button is a great way to discover all possible lookup values in a column before you run the full extraction. This helps avoid typos and ensures you get the data you expect.

pivot.title: Pivot Table Creator
pivot.description: Create a pivot table from your data by specifying row, column, and value fields, all without needing to open Excel. This tool can combine data from multiple sheets before pivoting.
pivot.whenToUse: Use this to quickly summarize large datasets. For example, to see total sales (value) broken down by salesperson (rows) and by product category (columns).
howToUse: Upload your workbook and select all sheets containing the source data.
Define your 'Row Fields', 'Column Fields' (optional), and the 'Value Field' to aggregate.
Choose the aggregation type (e.g., SUM, COUNT, AVERAGE).
Click 'Create Pivot Table' and download the new workbook containing the pivot table.
pivot.proTip: For complex analysis, you can specify multiple comma-separated columns in the 'Row Fields' and 'Column Fields' to create nested pivot table structures.

aggregator.title: Data Aggregator
aggregator.description: Analyze text across multiple sheets to count occurrences of specific keywords or phrases, based on your custom mapping rules.
aggregator.headerRowDesc: The row number containing your column titles (e.g., 1).
aggregator.searchColsDesc: Enter comma-separated column letters, names, or ranges (e.g., [code:A:C]) to search within.
aggregator.mappingsFileTooltipDesc: Upload a .txt, .csv, or .json file. For text files, use one 'value:key' pair per line. For JSON, use a single object of 'value':'key' pairs. You can also paste directly into the text area.
aggregator.mappingsPlaceholder: Enter one mapping per line (e.g., apple : Fruit). If no mapping is given (e.g., apple), it maps to itself.
aggregator.mappingsDesc: Define search terms and the reporting key they should map to. Use [code:value : key] format. Case-insensitive.

matchMode.title: Keyword Matching Mode
matchMode.wholeDesc: Matches only if the entire keyword is present as a standalone word (e.g., 'apple' matches 'apple pie' but not 'apples').
matchMode.partialDesc: Matches if the keyword appears anywhere within the cell's text (e.g., 'apple' matches 'pineapple').
matchMode.looseDesc: Matches if all words in the keyword appear in the cell, in any order (e.g., 'red apple' matches 'an apple that is red').

testRules.title: Test Your Rules
testRules.description: Before running on the whole file, test your mapping rules on a single row to see what key it will be assigned to.
testRules.missingTestInfo: Please select a sheet and enter a row number to test.
testRules.invalidTestRow: Please enter a valid row number greater than 0.
testRules.conditionalSkip: Conditional check passed: Column '{columnName}' is not empty ('{value}'). Skipping keyword search for this row.
testRules.conditionalProceed: Conditional check passed: Column '{columnName}' is empty. Proceeding with keyword search.
testRules.noKeywordsMatched: -> No keywords matched in this cell.
testRules.summaryMessage: This row will be counted under the key '{key}'.
testRules.noMatchesFound: No keywords matched for this row.

aggregator.valueMatchDesc: Counts based on finding your keywords in the 'Search Columns'. Use this for analyzing text.

conditionalMatch.label: Enable Conditional Matching
conditionalMatch.description: Only search for keywords in a row if a specific column in that row is empty. Useful for filling in blanks.

aggregator.keyMatchDesc: Counts based on the exact values found in a single 'Key Column'. Use this for summarizing existing categories.
aggregator.keyCountColDesc: The column containing the categories you want to count.
aggregator.discoverNewKeysDesc: Automatically find and add any unique values from the Key Column that aren't in your mappings list.
aggregator.blankLabelDesc: This text will be used to represent rows where the key/value cell is empty.

blankCountingMethod.title: Blank Counting Method
blankCountingMethod.rowAwareDesc: Counts a blank in the key column only if other cells in the same row contain data.
blankCountingMethod.fullColumnDesc: Counts every empty cell in the key column within the data range, ignoring other cells.

aggregator.blankDetailsDesc: Create an extra sheet listing every row that was counted as blank, along with its data.

reportingScope.title: Reporting Scope
reportingScope.description: Control which sheets are included in the standalone report file. This does not affect the sheets selected for processing.

aggregator.stripFormulasDesc: Before processing, convert all formulas to their calculated values. Helps prevent errors with complex formulas.
aggregator.updateColDesc: After finding a match, this column will be filled with the final mapped key.
aggregator.updateOnlyBlanksDesc: Only fill the cell in the 'Column to Update' if it is empty. Prevents overwriting existing data. Highlights updated cells in yellow.

pairedValidation.title: Enable Paired Row Validation
pairedValidation.description: Only update a blank cell if it has an adjacent row (above or below) with identical values in specific columns.

aggregator.updateReportDesc: Creates an extra sheet detailing every cell that was updated.
aggregator.fillKeyColumnDesc: In Value Match mode, finds the best keyword match for a row and fills the specified key column with that result.
aggregator.markMatchedRowsDesc: After finding a match, writes a specific value to a new column.
aggregator.markValueDesc: This value will be written in the 'Column to Mark' for every row that matches a keyword.
aggregator.insertSummaryAction: Insert Summary Results into Each Sheet
aggregator.insertSummaryDesc: Adds a summary table of the counts directly into each processed sheet.
aggregator.clearExistingSummaryDesc: If a summary with the same title already exists, it will be removed first.

summaryDataSource.title: Summary Data Source
summaryDataSource.useReportingScopeDesc: The summary will include a row for every key found across all processed sheets (consistent layout).
summaryDataSource.useLocalSheetDesc: The summary will be tailored to each sheet, creating a cleaner report.
summaryDataSource.showOnlyLocalKeysDesc: When checked, only shows keys with a count > 0 on the local sheet. Uncheck to show all keys for a consistent layout.

valueGeneration.title: Value Generation
valueGeneration.staticValuesDesc: The summary will contain the final, calculated numbers.
valueGeneration.liveFormulasDesc: The summary will use COUNTIF or SUMPRODUCT formulas to be dynamic.
valueGeneration.liveFormulasTooltip: Formulas can only be generated in Key Match mode.

aggregator.specialRowFormattingDesc: Apply distinct styles to the 'Total' and '(Blanks)' rows in the summary.
aggregator.showBlanksInInSheetDesc: If unchecked, the row for blank counts will be hidden from the in-sheet summary.

advancedSettings.title: Advanced Report Settings
advancedSettings.maxRowsDesc: If the report is very large, it will be split into multiple sheets to avoid performance issues.
advancedSettings.sheetsAsRowsDesc: Each row represents a sheet, and each column represents a key. Good for comparing sheets.
advancedSettings.keysAsRowsDesc: Each row represents a key, and each column represents a sheet. Good for many keys.
advancedSettings.autoSizeColumnsDesc: Automatically adjust column widths in the report sheets for better readability.
advancedSettings.hideColumnsDesc: Comma-separated list of key names or sheet names to exclude from the final report sheets.
advancedSettings.groupReportSheetTitleDesc: The name of the main summary sheet in the downloaded Group Report workbook.
advancedSettings.groupReportMultiSourceTitleDesc: This title is used when the report combines sheets with different dynamic titles (e.g., from cell A1).
advancedSettings.groupReportDescriptionPlaceholder: Optional: Add a description to appear at the top of the group report.

aggregator.createGroupReportDesc: Group your final keys into new categories for a high-level summary.

Example format:
Group A: Key1, Key2

aggregator.editKeysDesc: You can merge keys by renaming them to be the same (e.g., rename 'apple' and 'apples' both to 'Apple').
